titleStmt.title: J. M. Quinton to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG4467

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To His Excellency, the Govenor of Kentucky;

J. M. Quinton ^Your petitioner^ States that about the 14th day of August, 1863, he was fined thirty dollars in the Police Court of Harrodsburg for a breach of the peace, Said alledged offence growing out of a fight between Your petitioner and one Emanuel Garcia, a Mexican, and for a long time a Soldier in John H- Morgan's Command. Your petitioner further States that the Said Emanuel Garcia while attached to the command of Morgan, during one of his raids into Kentucky, caome to the house of Your petitioner -- durring his absences and while he was a refugee from home on account of his Union principles and Searched for your petitioner and insultingly demanded of his wife to make known his whereabouts, at the some time making threats &c -- ; and that afterwards when Said Garcia had deserted Morgan and came home your petitioner meeting him asked him about his conduct at his house and that on receiving an insulting reply Your petitioner whipped the native Mexican and rebel deserter; and that the breach of the peace charged consisted in this. J. M. Quinton further states that at the time such insults were offered to his family he was, and is now, a discharged Union Soldier, having served in the 19th Ky regiment under Col. Landrum
for nearly a year and discharged on account of physical disability. On account of these facts he asks of your Excellency a favorable consideration in his behalf J. M. Quinton states on oath he believes the statements in the foregoing petition are true,, Sworn to before me this 3rd Novr 1863 and that his knowledge of said Garcia being at his houses is based on information of his family; the other statements of the petition he knows to be true
Subscribed and Sworn to before me this 3 December, 1863 --

John G. Kyle,
Police Judge of Harrodsburg.
We the undersigned citizens of Mercer County Would urge and request Your Excellency to, remit the fine of J. M. Quinton, believing him to be especially an object of clemency --

JW. V. Frapnall
O S Poston
Thos Edwards P J M C C
J, L, Smedley
John G- Kyle
James D Hardin
C, S, Abner
Richard Board C. M. C. C
W, E, Riley
George Frapnall

Harrodsburg ky
Decr 16 1863
Dear Governor Bramlette
Dear Sir
I present the enclosed petition for your consideration and execative clemency Trusting that at an early day you will give it a perusal

Respectfully
Your friend
O S Poston

Remit except fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette
